Sir,

With further reference to the Jack Head school house being unfit for occupation as soon as the spring comes on or rain commences, I beg to state that I mentioned the matter to the band when there on the 9th inst., but as they intend building a new one, they do not care about doing anything on the old house.

The Councillor however offered the building which had been rented by Mr. Wood last spring and if accepted on the same terms would put a new roof on it if required. Being covered with boards it is subject to leaking during heavy rains. The building would be necessary as long as

Sir,

I have the honor to inclose herewith a letter, dated the 15th, from Mr. Agent MacKay, with reference to the condition of the Jack Head School-house, and suggesting that a house of the Commissioners be rented for use as a School-house while the Indians are erecting a new building.

I would respectfully recommend that the house in question be rented at the rate of $42 per month, from the time the rain shall commence to the 1st July next.

of Indian Affairs,

Department of Indian Affairs,

Ottawa, Feb 17th 1892

As the building which Agent Mackay has requested authority to rent for use as a school-house at Jack Head will only be required for four or five months and therefore the expenditure will only be $1500 or $2000 I think there will be funds available and I would recommend that Mr. M. J.W.

MEMORANDUM

Department of Indian Affairs,

Ottawa, 3rd Sept., 1892

With reference to Mr. Smith's letter of the 30th July, I have to report that the erection of a house for school purposes on the Jack Head Res. has been completed. The facts are as follows:

On the 7th July last Mr. McColl recommended that owing to the condition of the school house, the house belonging to the Commissioner be rented at the rate of $4.00 per month for the time the new house would commence to be used by the Indians in building the new school house. On the 25th of the same month the necessary authority was given to rent the house for the time specified.

On the 28th June last Mr. McColl reported among other things that the arrangement for buying lumber from the Fisher House Mills to be used by the Indians in building the new school house could not be carried out & the appropriation for the school having
MEMORANDUM.

To Department of Indian Affairs,

Ottawa, 189—

Having been informed out of the Estimates for 1891-92 by the Comptroller that he requested to be informed whether he might not instruct the Agent to rent a house for school purposes for a longer period than that referred to as there would be no use in sending a teacher to that school unless suitable arrangements could be made to keep the school open for more than one or two months as it is a long and expensive trip. No reply was given to this inquiry and on the 18th July last he repeated the request. On the 23rd ult. he was informed that it was understood that the school house was to have been completed by the 25th July and that the school had been in operation since the authority was given to rent the house referred to for that purpose and that the Dept. must have a report on these points before any authority could be given.
MEMORANDUM

To Department of Indian Affairs,

Ottawa

...to rent the house for longer than 4 or 5 months. Mr. McColl has already given his reasons why the school house was not completed by that time arrangement for conveying the teacher cannot be carried out & besides the application was struck out of the Estimates for 1892 as to the School's not being in operation after the authority was given to rent the house Agent MacKay reports he had letter of the 28th March last enclosed in McColl's letter of the 16th May last that the teacher was engaged temporarily by him with the understanding that his wife would teach in his place when he was absent on duty as catechet & that he had directed the teacher to close the school at the end of April 26 & that he warned he careful in future not to interfere in the temporary absence of teachers. It will thus be seen that he ordered the School to be closed about the time...

time he was instructed by Mr. McColl to rent the house referred to. That does not appear to be any appropriation in the estimates for the Cement near to cover the erection of a school house on this site; but there was an item of $1000 voted in last year's Estimates for repair and furniture. It goes without saying that the school should be kept in operation & the question of renting a house for school purposes until a school house can be erected is one for consideration. OTTAWA 19th April, 1894

Sir,

I enclose herewith a copy of a letter received from Peter Stony and other Indians of Jack Head in which they ask for the erection of a school building in a more central locality than that which they now possess. Upon examining the plan of this Reserve it is found that a school site of 10 acres is laid out on the bank of the Jack Fish River, in what would appear to be a very central and convenient locality. The Department would be glad if you would furnish a report on the statements made by the Indians who should be informed that this and similar communication should be transmitted to the Department through their Agent.

Your obedient servant,

Lake Head
30th March '94

To the Hon'ble Minister
of Interior
Superintendent of Indian Affairs
Ottawa

Sir,

We, the Chief and band of Indians (Treaty No. 5), located on the Indian reserve at Lake Head, situated on the west side of Lake Winnipeg in the Province of Manitoba.

We most respectfully approach your honor to request that you graciously grant us this our request—that a new building may be erected, and set apart for a school house, in some part of our reserve, which will be central, so as to allow of an equal distance from children to attend, as it is at present too long a distance from the school, and a number of our Indians reside too far up the river to send their children to the small school house at present fitted for that purpose, near the mouth of the river.

We would also desire that proper furniture may be furnished the same, as the present outfit is too small quite to accommodate the pupils.

The poor children many of them have to sit on the floor and have therefore not got so much inclination to attend a school so badly fitted up.

We would also request that a space be allowed to the school for a play ground and room to place the fire during the winter months. We also beg to remark that it is impossible for the school master with whom we...
We are well satisfied to carry out the strict observance of school rules, or an encouragement for the children to attend regularly, as they are directed.

We hope therefore that an early consideration will be taken in favor of our present desire, as we have been made to understand frequently, that a new school should be granted to us like the one at Nishnabotna Reserve and other reserves, at an early date.

We have the honor to be,

Your most obedient humble servants

Sir,

I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 14th instant, re paying rent for the use of the Jack Head School house, whilst a cheque had been sent for the purchase of the building, and to point out that the arrangement for the purchase having been made only in the latter part of July, 1897, on Mr Inspector McColl's annuity payment journey, the papers in this connection could not reach Ottawa sooner than they actually did, and the cheque for $50.00 consequently left Ottawa only during the latter part of August, and under ordinary circumstances could not reach its destination until after September, the mail service being a matter of chance. Under the circumstances it seems natural that the owner of the property felt justified in claiming rent for the September Quarter, which claim was duly endorsed by Mr Indian Agent Short, and forwarded in due time to the Department for payment.

I may add that the arrangements for the purchase were not guaranteed by Mr Inspector McColl, who said that they were subject to the approval of the Department, and until the receipt of the cheque Mr Travers ignored that the bargain had been found satisfactory and authorized by the Department.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter No. II8274/I of the 22nd ultimo requesting a report of repairs and equipment to enable the Jack Head School to be re-opened.

I respectfully beg to state that the School building appears to be in need of re-plastering, whitewashing and cleaning, generally.

It will also be necessary to provide stove pipes and perhaps a new stove as the one at the Jack Head School has been thickly coated with rust for many years.

The supply of books and other equipment has been entirely destroyed by mice so that it will be necessary to furnish a full equipment for this school. I have inserted in the estimates for the fiscal year of 1920-1921 a sum of $100.00 for repairs and equipment for the Jack Head School.

There are about 35 children of school age in the Jack Head Reserve whose parents will claim are protestants but I would say most of the people at Jack Head are pagan.

There is a fair house belonging to the Church of England just outside of the northern boundary of the Jack Head reserve, which with a little repair can be made very comfortable as a residence for the teacher. It is to be hoped that a person who has had plenty of experience with Indians will be selected for the Jack Head school.

Native teachers are useless.

I have the honour to be your obedient servant,

Indian Agent,

Referring to your letter No. 118274-1 of the 15th ultimo I respectfully beg to submit the following estimate of cost of repairs and equipment for the Jack Head Day School:

- Box stove, pipes, damper, wire, roof-top and jack: $20.00
- Plastering & whitewashing, including lime & brush: $25.00
- Window glass, putty, nails and outside door set: $5.00
- Equipment, including slates, pencils, readers, scribblers, reading cards, ball frame, hand bell etc.: $25.00
- Freighting supplies to Jack Head: $35.00

Total: $110.00

To erect a residence similar to those in connection with the schools upon the Peguis Reserve would entail a cost of between $500.00 and $600.00, owing to the cost of freighting materials and the extra cost of labour which could not be obtained in the Jack Head Reserve.

As stated in my letter of the 3rd instant, there is a house belonging to the Church of England just outside of the Jack Head Reserve which could no doubt be rented for use of the teacher, but would require some repairs. Although I do not think repairs to this house would cost more than about $50.00, I could not be sure as I have not seen the interior for some years and I should judge the stoves and pipes I last saw in the house would now be worthless.

This house is situated just outside the northern line of the reserve and is less than a mile from the school.

I have the honour to be your obedient servant,

Indian Agent,
Fisher River Agency.

Sir:

Commissioner Graham has forwarded to the Department a copy of your letter of the 28th ultimo reporting on your recent visit to the Jackhead Indian Day School.

With reference to the repairs required, I beg to say that you may have a new floor laid, a new door installed, the necessary quantity of roofing placed on the south side of the building and the interior whitewashed. Properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, should be forwarded covering the expenditure incurred in carrying out the repairs to the school building and in the erection of the toilets.

Dear Mr Lazenby:

Having regard to the psychological reactions of the pupils, as well as the reactions on the disposition of the teacher, I would say that the interior conditions of the school are far from inspiring. In fact they are rather depressing. I shall try to make the picture a bit clearer.

The school is a log structure, on cement foundation, bearded gables, shingled roof. All is good material, flooring good, and ceiling of matched lumber. Inside dimensions are: Length 30 feet width 20 feet height of wall from floor to ceiling 8 feet.

The logs are plastered along the cracks, and the whole lime washed. However, the trouble is that plaster drops out continually and lime-wash rubs off easily. The ceiling was long ago painted a dull grey, and never repainted.

There is on the West side only 40' Sq feet of window light. On the east side there is none at all. There is only 50 sq feet of black board, this on north end. There are only nine double desks, the same being in the last stages of dissolution. They hold together by the grace of fish cord bindings and fish box reinforcement. One seat consists of an empty biscuit box. To the best of my information these desks are about forty years old.

I would suggest that the walls be stripped with 1x2 inch boards 2 feet apart, then lined with shiplap, a layer of building paper and the whole covered with Ten Test. On the east wall there should be at least 60 sq feet of Black board and the old black board on the North wall renewed. There should also be four transom windows high up on the east wall. This for added light and ventilation.

Should the above suggested improvements receive favourable consideration, I attach for your convenience a list of approximate quantities of materials required for the work.

Yours faithfully

GEO E JEFFERY
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept' of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

I beg to forward herewith in duplicate, requisition for new desks for the Jackhead Day School, also, on a separate requisition, a new heating stove for the same school, with a copy of a letter, written by the teacher, Mr. Geo: E.Jeffery.

I would strongly recommend that these two requisitions be approved.

Attached also, is a list of materials, showing the estimated cost, with labour, for the repairing and improving of this school. I would recommend that the purchase of this material, and the use of the labour, for the construction be authorized. With regard to the wages of the 'Supervisor', Mr Jeffery, who is a fairly good carpenter, suggested that if he were to receive wages at the rate he is paid for teaching, he would stay there for the necessary time during the summer holidays, and supervise the work. Kindly advise.

P.G. Lazenby
Indian Agent.

Mr McLean:

In reference to the grant made for a day school at or near Norway House to be conducted under the auspices of the Church of England, and which is objected to by the Methodist Church authorities on the ground that that district properly belongs to their mission field, I beg to say that the Department has always recognized the claim of the Methodist Church to this particular section of country and I think that they are quite justified in their objection to having another denomination poaching upon their preserves. But I think that if you will read the application of the Bishop of Moosonee for the grant above referred to, you will see that he had no intention of entering the field in opposition to the Methodists. The Indians for whose benefit he wishes a school established are non-treaty and have always belonged to the Church of England, and although he mentions the locality by
the name of Norway House, that title is merely given to designate the neighborhood, as you will see by reference to the map showing Treaty 5, you will see that the boundaries of that Treaty extend only some thirty miles east of the Norway House Reserve.

The Methodists still have two schools in this district, Rossville and Norway House which are inside treaty and have lately applied for two more schools in this neighborhood, outside treaty.

It is a difficult matter to fix the exact position of any place in this unsettled region, as the same locality is called by different names by different people.

I think it well that you should have this additional information before you, although I did not feel called upon to make it official.

The Deputy Superintendent General:

With reference to the application submitted by Mr McCreary, M.P., for the recognition of a Church of England day school for the instruction of Indian and half-breed children at Jack River or Playgreen Lake in the Heren's River Agency, I beg to say that the Church of England has a day school in operation there which the Indian Commissioner states is successfully conducted and regularly attended by treaty as well as non-treaty Indians.

Mr Agent Semmens, who visited this school last month reports that a new schoolhouse was built last summer by the Indians, assisted by a carpenter brought from Selkirk, and that they have a fine schoolhouse. There were 11 children present on the day he visited the school and it was quite up to the standard of the other schools in this Agency.

As you will see in my memo. of the 4th Nov. last, provision was at one time made for this school, but no payments were ever made as the Methodists protested against its recognition. The school is situated in the Norway House district, which they claim as their mission field. Mr Agent Semmens, however, who is a Methodist minister, considers that a school doing such good work is entitled to the support of
the Department. My memorandum was submitted to the Deputy Minister, who sent it on to the Superintendent General. His decision then was "Nothing at present".

Rev. Mr. Burman points out that it is impossible for the children attending this school to go to the one at Rossville, owing to the distance (about six miles) with long stretches of water to be crossed.

The Church of England apparently has a footing at Jack River and it seems to me that Mr. Semmen's favorable report on the school should override the objection of the Methodists to its recognition.

This is one of the schools for which the Bishop of Keewatin lately applied for a grant, but without success.

OTTAWA, 27th March, 1903.

The Deputy Superintendent General:

In further reference to the application for the recognition of the Jack River school I beg to say that a school was established at this point in 1884 by the Church of England, and has, with several intermissions, been carried on ever since, being now in operation.

On the 5th Nov. 1900 Dr Sutherland wrote to the Department protesting against the re-opening of this school which had been closed for about a year, claiming that this district was under their supervision, they formerly having had a school called Jack River, which had been closed and has not since been re-opened owing to the recognition of the boarding school at Norway House.

In view of Dr Sutherland's protest the Minister directed that the Ch. of England school should not be recognized and the Commissioner was so informed. However, the grant for this school has been continued in the Estimates and is provided for in the current year and for next year also. A return was received from this school for Dec. quarter last; none having been received for over a year previously and as Mr Sutherland, who has charge of the payments, finding the money available in the estimates, prepared a requisition for the amount shown to be earned by the return, and a Cheque for $52.27 was sent the teacher.

The trouble about this school has originated in the similarity of the names of Jack Head and Jack River, which are one and the same place. The Methodists have abandoned their school and the Ch. of England wishes to continue theirs. The Department has made provision for the Methodist children by making a grant to the Norway House Boarding school which has a day school attachment, called Rossville.

The physical formation of the country renders it necessary that there should be a day school at Jack River, and as the Ch. of England has been there for such a length of time I think it would be only right that they should receive the grant.

ANGELICAN SCHOOL:

At Norway House the Anglican school in charge of the Rev J. Marshall is doing good work. The buildings are in fair condition, new seats have been put in and Mr Marshall is very much interested in his work and anxious to make a success. Whether the building belongs to the Anglican Mission Association or to the Government I am unable to say. As is the case with all the other schools in this district there are times in the year when it is impossible for pupils to attend the school owing to the ice forming upon the river and lakes or at the breaking up of the ice. Another great drawback to regular attendance is the custom of travelling away in the winter time to their hunting grounds with parents or to the regular fishing grounds in the summer. As you are well aware of these circumstances you will be able to understand the great drawback this is to the successful education of Indian children in the ordinary day schools.

My dear Sir,

In reply to yours of the 10th inst., I beg to say that I approve of the appointment of Mrs. W. Gall as teacher of the Jack River Anglican Indian Day School in succession to Miss E. Finlayson.

With regard to Mr. Walter's request that, in order to save time, cheques in payment of the teacher's salary be sent direct to him and that he could then endorse and hand them to the teacher, there are several reasons why I think it advisable to make a change in procedure in this regard. In the first place as you are aware it is found advisable often that the missionary should be also the teacher, in which case the salary from the Department is only a portion of the stipend of the missionary who receives his full stipend each quarter out of Diocesan funds, the Department's cheque acting as a refund for payments already made. While there is no likelihood of a change in this regard in the near future, should the present missionary be changed it would be a very likely action if we could get a qualified missionary as teacher, especially in view of the fact that the teacher has to live with the missionary.

In the second place as you are aware the school in Indian missions is under the church carrying on the mission and is part of the missionary administration and is so recognized by the Department. The fact that the salary is paid by the Department through the Diocesan authorities rather than through the local missionary makes this plain to the teacher, and constitutes an important link between the Church authorities, the Department, and the teacher.

I have written to Mr. Walter with regard to the third point, the saving of time, that this would be better accomplished if the teacher would open an account in a bank to which the salary should be sent as the chief delay is caused by the remoteness of the school from banking facilities, and also for six months of the year from a Post Office, other than the isolated Post Office at Norway House.

For these reasons I think a change is inadvisable.

I beg to remain,

Very faithfully yours,

Sir,

I beg to report that on the 13th instant I inspected the Jack River Church of England Indian Day School.

This is a combined school, there being 36 pupils on the roll, 18 of which are Indian, and 18 non-Indian. All 36 pupils were present on the day of my visit, and the register was marked up to date.

The teacher, Miss Evelyn Hope, is efficient, and with the exception of one pupil who appears to be mentally sub-normal, teacher and pupils are making good progress.

There is a shortage of pupils' desks at this school, and several of the pupils were sitting on upturned biscuit boxes, and using desks improvised from biscuit boxes and old boards. It was noticeable that the pupils who are sitting on the biscuit boxes were physically tired before the close of the school day, and under such circumstances they cannot be expected to do good work. This also reflects on the teacher, as she cannot possibly get as good results from such pupils. There are, however, sufficient desks to accommodate the strictly Indian pupils. I am of the opinion that one of three policies should be adopted in connection with this school, namely: Provide eight or ten new double desks; limit the pupilage to about 20 to 24; or exclude all non-Indian children.

I understand that the Manitoba Provincial Government makes a grant for this school, yearly, though what the amount of the grant is, I do not know, but I believe it is not very much. If it is desired to continue the school as at present, and accommodate these non-Indian children, I think the Provincial Government be approached with a view to having them bear at least a fair portion of the cost of new desks.

The inside walls of this school would be much the better for either painting or lime-washing, to brighten the room up. At present, they are very dirty, and depressing.

Your obedient Servant,

P.G. Lazemey,
Indian Agent.

Sir,

I beg to report that on the 20th instant, I inspected the Jack River Combined White and Indian Church of England Day School.

On the day of my visit, there were 29 pupils on the roll, 17 being treaty Indian children, and 12 non treaty children. Of these, there were present 6 treaty Indian pupils, and 11 non treaty pupils. The attendance had been very good until the 9th April, but after Easter, the attendance of treaty children dropped greatly, due to some of the parents taking the children with them when they went trapping muskrats. There was but one non treaty pupil absent.

There are a number of Indian children in the vicinity of our school who have no mother, and whose father is often away trapping. Not only do these children lack nourishment and clothing to enable them to attend school, but in addition, the roads here during rainy season are very poor. Now we have a good two-story building here just beside the school which could easily be made comfortable. We use it as a carpenter shop. Dear Mr. Rogers:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 8th instant, in which you seek additional information with respect to the grant allowed by this Branch to the Jack River Combined Day School.

A report received by this Department from Inspector Hamilton, dated January 17, 1940, indicates that the average attendance of Indian children at this school amounted to 4.58. At that time we were allowing a grant of $650.00 a year to this school and, in addition, were purchasing annually a supply of Eskimo biscuits and cocoa for the Indian pupils.

Our estimates this year have been drastically reduced, with the result that all Indian schools in the Dominion will operate this year on a 9 month rather than a 10 month basis. It will not be possible, therefore, for us to increase our allowance to the Jack River School.

The matter of providing education for half-breed children is one that has been reviewed from time to time, particularly by the educational authorities in Alberta, but so far no definite decision has been reached. The term "Half-breed" in my judgment is somewhat unfortunate. The inhabitants of Canada are either citizens in the usual sense that we speak of citizens or Indians as defined by

C. K. Rogers, Esq.,
Chief Administrative Officer,
Department of Education,
Legislative Buildings,
Winnipeg, Manitoba.
the Indian Act. The appropriations voted by Parliament from year to year are voted on the distinct understanding that the money so voted will be used for the education and general welfare of the Indian population. Payments made by the Branch from time to time are carefully reviewed by the Treasury officials, with the object of determining if these expenditures have been made in conformity with the provisions of the Indian Act and the wishes of Parliament. This procedure is in striking contrast to the procedure followed in the old days, prior to the organization of the provinces of Alberta and Saskatchewan. In those days the Dominion Government scarcely ever differentiated between Indian children and half-breed children living the Indian mode of life on reserves. Since I entered the Department, however, definite instructions have been received from the office of the Minister that the education of Indian children as defined by the Indian Act, and Indian children alone, is the responsibility of the Dominion Government.

I appreciate very fully, of course, that these comments are not likely to prove very helpful to you in your attempts to keep the Jack River School open and in operation. In view of the fact, however, that it appears impossible for us to increase our grant, the only suggestion I can make is that consideration be given to the desirability of reducing still further the annual operating period of the school.

Yours sincerely,

I beg to report that I visited the Jack River C of E Combined Day School on the 20th instant.

At the time of my visit there were 27 pupils present, 7 of these being treaty Indians, and 20 non-treaty. There were 10 names of Indian pupils on the roll. The register was marked up to date. The average attendance of Indian pupils, from April 1st to the date of my visit was a fraction over 6.

The teacher, Mrs C.R.Harbord, was efficient in her work.

Reading aloud was good apart from the usual monotone generally used by Indian children. The book work was very good, neat, and accurate. Singing by the whole school was also very good, some two part songs being sung.

I wish to submit the following report on the schools of the Norway House Agency, inspected in June, 1946.

Jack River Indian Day School

Mrs. Harboard is in charge at this school. The roll calls for 20 and June average was 10.6.

The school is in good repair; but some paint is needed. The new doors supplied some time ago are still not painted.

The yards were clean and well kept. The new flag pole erected recently adds to the surroundings. The out toilets were clean and in good condition.

The school books seen would indicate that the children are making fair progress.

There are 28 non-treaty children enrolled and I understand ten new seats are on order. These certainly are needed.

Rossville Indian Day School

Mrs. Scott is the teacher in charge. The roll calls for 31 and I found 25 present. The grades are as follows:

| Grade | Roll |
|-------|------|
| 1     | 21   |
| 2     | 8    |
| 3     | 2    |
| 4     | 2    |
| 5     | 2    |
| 6     | 2    |

The average attendance is good. There are not enough seats. Some single seats of different sizes should be provided. The floor is painted. The walls are covered with V-joint and painted. This school is a very old building but in fair condition.

Mrs. Scott is doing very good work. The children read out well and appear to be well along in their different grades. She also teaches handicraft work and some of the work seen was indeed quite good.

Jack River R.C. Indian School

One of the Sisters is in charge and from the exercise books would judge the pupils are making fair progress.

There are 18 boarders and 3 day pupils. I understand the boarders are considered part of the Cross Lake School and are included in their school returns.
Jack River R.C. School (contd.)

The building is old, but fairly well arranged and the pupils are well cared for and well supervised. The classroom is especially bright and cheerful and the pupils appear very happy. The day pupils live quite close to school and are fairly regular in their attendance.

Cross Lake Indian Day School - United Church

Miss K. Neufeld is in charge, but she did not expect to return. There were 9 Indian children and 10 non-treaty enrolled.

I was at the reserve on Saturday so did not see the children in class. I understand Miss Neufeld has done very good work.

The building is made of logs and the inside is lined with ten-teak. The outside is covered with siding and presents a fair appearance.

Another day school is needed as there are about 40 pupils for which no provision is made. I would refer the Department to previous correspondence as submitted by Agent Lazenby.

Cross Lake R.C. Indian Boarding School

There are 26 pupils enrolled and all but the Cross Lake pupils had left before my arrival.

This was my first visit to the new school and I was greatly impressed with the very excellent building.

The dormitories were spotless, well aired and very bright. The beds were quite close together but with all the windows I am sure the children have plenty of fresh air. The bedding was clean and there was abundant.

The classrooms were very bright and the walls nicely decorated. The desks, although in use for some years, were almost without a scratch. I am certain from the books seen that the Sisters do very excellent work in the classroom.

I examined the work done in the sewing-room and must admit that the girls do splendid sewing. They make dresses, knit all kinds of garments and do very excellent patch work and darning.

The kitchen and dining rooms were in excellent order and the girls receive a good training in cooking and baking. The children seem were in good health and I am sure are well cared for and well fed.

This school is situated in an isolated area and the Rev. Father is greatly concerned and rightly so about his engine and generator. If the engine should fail at any time the school would be without light or water - in fact, it could not continue to operate. I think a second unit should be installed. There is plenty of room, consequently no additional expense will be required for building purposes. The total cost would be for the engine, generator and water for someone to see that it is properly installed. I think the Department should give this request serious consideration. If the school were closer to town I would not make the recommendation; but a bad break in equipment at this isolated point would be serious and perhaps repairs could not be secured for weeks. There are often weeks when communication to the outside is impossible and this is especially bad at freeze-up and again in the spring during break-up.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6237, file 519-1, part 2)
Cross Lake Boarding School (contd.)

The hot water tank which hangs by the furnace also must be renewed. I understand Mr. Lazenby has the particulars and is submitting the necessary requisition. This should be ordered and sent forward at once.

The school has a large garden; which this year was planted late and of course was not up when I was there. The Rev. Father keeps some very fine Holstein cows, a flock of hens and some pigs. The school is under excellent management and the children appeared very happy. The operating of such an excellent school in this remote area is a great credit to the Church and Government. The Rev. Father Trudeau is interested in his work and is assisted by an excellent staff of Sisters.

God's Lake U.C. Day School

The school building is small and is the property of the United Church. It is a log building and in fair repair. The teacher last year was Miss Elsie Hiebert. The grades are as follows:

| Grade | Number |
|-------|--------|
| 1     | 14     |
| 2     | 4      |
| 3     | 6      |
| 4     | 1      |
| Total | 25     |

The attendance for the June quarter was 65. I noticed six pupils had not attended at all during the quarter. There is no teacher's residence in connection with this school and the teacher must board with the Missionary. I understand Miss Hiebert has resigned.

These Indians are trappers and hunters and so are away from the reserve for weeks at a time. It seems impossible to operate a day school with any degree of success under such conditions.

Oxford House U.C. Indian Day School

Mrs. Deuck was in charge but she had already left.

This is a log school and I found it in fair condition. The building needed interior painting as the walls were dark.

I did not see the register. I understand there are at least 40 children for which there is no classroom accommodation.

Island Lake U.C. Indian Day School

The teacher, Miss E. Loewen, had left before I arrived. The roll showed 42 - three in grade 2 and the balance in grade 1.

This is a log school. Some repair is needed to the roof and the floor needs painting. The material is on hand, I understand, and the work will be carried out during the summer.

If we had a school residence I would recommend that a married couple be engaged and that they do social and welfare work, as well as teach. They should be hired by the year with, say, a month's holidays. They could then supervise a good garden and help in the...
Island Lake R.C.Day School (contd.)

organization of social groups. The women could instruct and help the Indian women in the sewing clubs and social organizations. A married couple interested in the work would be a great help to the Agent and could do very excellent work. There are about 160 United Church children of school age. If these are to be accommodated in day schools we would need three more schools. These Indians are trappers and I doubt if day schools can even be considered as an answer to the great need. The parents cannot remain on the reserve in the winter and trap, and the children cannot be away with their parents and attend a day school; consequently there appears only one solution and that is more boarding schools.

Island Lake R.C.Day School

Mr. J.M. Blackburn is in charge of the school at Maria Portage. He is doing very excellent work.

The building is in fair condition and the school work seen was good.

I understand there are about 54 pupils enrolled with an average attendance in June of 30. There are 27 in grade 1; 13 in grade 2; 7 in grade 3; 4 in grade 4; 3 in grade 5. The teacher and his wife live in a nearby house, the property of the R.C.Mission, and for which the Department pay to the Mission a yearly rental of $75.00.

I wish to recommend that this school be taken over by the Indian Affairs Branch as an Indian Day School. That the teacher be paid the current basic salary paid to other Day School teachers in this Agency.

My reasons are as follows:

1. The present arrangement whereby the Indian Affairs Branch and the Province of Manitoba each donate a pittance towards the teacher's salary and the maintenance of the school has proved most unsatisfactory.

2. The building is the property of the Indian Affairs Branch. It is in good condition.

3. I understand that the Government of Manitoba is building a new two room school to accommodate the white and non-treaty children of this district.

4. There are 62 treaty Indian children who should be attending this school.

5. This school is closed at present as there is no teacher, and under present conditions I doubt if one will be procurable, unless it is a missionary who would take over the school as a side line. This arrangement would be unsatisfactory and unfair both to the children and the Missionary.

There is no teacher's residence, and I further recommend that one be built, and that this be kept in mind when the post war building plan gets under way. I notice that no estimate has been made for such a residence.

I trust that the foregoing will receive your sympathetic consideration.

I am sorry to have to inform you that for family reasons, Mr. J. P. Mullan withdrew from the appointment as Missionary-Teacher at Jack River, Norway House. He was to have gone from Winnipeg last week, and I was disappointed to learn by a letter written on the 1st inst. that he could not undertake the work. Our major difficulties at the Jack River School are that there is no teacherage, hence if the mission is vacant, as it is at present, there is no accommodation for a teacher, and even if we have a missionary in residence it may not be convenient to provide board and room for a teacher. The second difficulty is the smallness of the grant for a teacher, which makes it necessary for the Church to provide the major portion of a teacher's salary, even though it is at present a Combined School with an available grant of $320.00 per year from Manitoba Department of Education. Dear Mr Goodman,

Thank you for yours of the 16th ult., enclosing copy of a letter you have written to the Indian Affairs Branch with regard to the Jack River C of E Day School.

Your recommendation to the Branch have my fullest approval. Since 1940 when the Department seriously cut the grant for this school to a mere "pittance" we have laboured under difficulties, although we have tried to make it worth while for the wife of the missionary to teach school. On the resignation of the Rev. C.R. Harbord I advertised for a teacher for this school, and had there been a teacherage I could have engaged a lady teacher with due qualifications. I could not however send a lady teacher unless someone occupied the mission house who would provide accommodation, and as the mission was falling vacant that was not possible, and in any case we should have been required to provide the bulk of the salary, for even with the grant from the Province of Manitoba together with the small grant from the Indian Affairs Branch, the amount receivable would be altogether inadequate.

I had an application from a Mr. J.P. Mullan who I hoped would go in as Missionary-Teacher. I arranged for an interview at our expense, and received approval of his appointment from Ottawa, I had considerable correspondence with Mr. Mullan, and awaited his final decision before replying to your letter which I had hoped to advise you of his coming to Jack River. Much to my disappointment he wrote me last week to say that for family reasons he could not take up the work. I then tried a local man who is interested, and who knows Norway House. He gave it consideration and was favourably disposed, but on account of a growing son who will soon be of school age his wife did not favour the move. This I learned only yesterday. This latter plan would have provided lay administration for the mission but would not have solved the teacher problem. Now I fear it is too late to get anyone in this Fall.

Yours sincerely,

J Keewatin

Indian Affairs Branch, Dep't of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

I wish to recommend that this school be taken over by the Indian Affairs Branch as an Indian Day School. That the teacher be paid the current basic salary paid to other Day School teachers in this Agency.

My reasons are as follows:

1. The present arrangement whereby the Indian Affairs Branch and the Province of Manitoba each donate a pittance towards the teacher's salary and the maintenance of the school has proved most unsatisfactory.

2. The building is the property of the Indian Affairs Branch. It is in good condition.

3. I understand that the Government of Manitoba is building a new two room school to accommodate the white and non-treaty children of this district.

4. There are 62 treaty Indian children who should be attending this school.

5. This school is closed at present as there is no teacher, and under present conditions I doubt if one will be procurable, unless it is a missionary who would take over the school as a side line. This arrangement would be unsatisfactory and unfair both to the children and the Missionary.

There is no teacher's residence, and I further recommend that one be built, and that this be kept in mind when the post war building plan gets under way. I notice that no estimate has been made for such a residence.

I trust that the foregoing will receive your sympathetic consideration.

I am sending a copy of this letter to Bishop Lofthouse.

E.B. Goodman,
Indian Agent.

On Sept 16th, 1945, I wrote a letter to the Indian Affairs Branch concerning the C of E Day School at Jack River, a copy of which I enclose. To date I have received no reply to this letter.

I also enclose a copy of a letter I received from the Rt Rev J. Lofthouse D.D., Bishop of Keewatin.

Under existing conditions I doubt if it will be possible to procure a qualified teacher for this school.

There are 62 Treaty Indian children who should be attending this school and the parents repeatedly ask me when this school is to be opened. I have had several requests that their children be allowed to attend the R.C. Jack River Day School, which is already crowded.

On Oct 1st I received a letter from Mr Phelan informing me that this procedure was contrary to the Indian Act and he drew my attention to subsection 2 of Section 10.

While carrying out the Family Allowance Registration for this agency I took a census of children of school age; that is, of children born between 1929 and 1939. There are 852 children of school age. There is school accommodation for 510 children, leaving a balance of 375 children for whom there is no school accommodation. This figure does not include the 62 children of the Jack River C of E Day School which is closed.

The need for new schools in this agency is desperate. Several of our Day School buildings now in use are old, of log construction, inadequate and unsuitable, and should be condemned.

Is there any indication as to when this Post-War Building Plan as outlined for the Norway House Indian Agency will be commenced.

In my second letter to the Branch d/Oct 30, I think I made this point quite clear. In case I did not, there are 62 Treaty Indian children whose names and ages I obtained from Mrs Harbord before she left. My reference to travelling expenses of Mr. Poole as per letter of this date enclosed brings to mind further expenses entailed during the past summer on Indian work.

On the incoming trip I took Mr. Harold Garrett who was to teach school for the summer at Trout Lake. This latter was service for the Indian Affairs Branch, for Mr. Garrett had no other means of getting in to Trout Lake. Such a trip for Mr. Garrett would have cost at least $100.00.

On July 28th I left Churchill by chartered plane to Duck Lake, Caribou Post, to minister to our Chipewyan Indians. That trip cost $191.25.

I had of course to take these trips in the performance of my duties, and I rejoice to be of service to our Indian people. I feel that the Department should know that the Church renders such service where and whenever possible thereby saving some expense for the Department. Dear Sir:

Re: File 519-1 (E)
Jack River C.E. Indian Day School.

Thank you for your letter of July 18 which came to hand on August 6th on my return from an extended visitation of our Indian Missions in the Hudson Bay area and the northern end of Lake Winnipeg, which occupied my time and attention for a month.

I visited Churchill, York Factory and Jack River, Norway House, as well as other points in the northern area of our Diocese, including Split Lake. Teachers are required for York Factory, Jack River and Split Lake, and thus far we have no applicants for any of them. We should be pleased to hear from you as to any Anglican applicants, or other suitable teachers.

I may say that on the occasion of my visit to Split Lake from July 22nd to 25th, the teacherage was not erected, although it was expected that the same would be duly constructed by Mr. Bland and Mr. Hadley, the Hudson's Bay manager and free trader respectively.

It is understood that Mr. Retallack, the Hudson's Bay Company manager at York Factory is being transferred, hence I presume the services of Mrs. Retallack as teacher will not for long be available.

Yours sincerely,

Col. Bernard F. Neary,

Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.

Dear Col. Neary:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 25th ult. with reference to Mr. Cranston and the above school.

Since early in September I have been in communication with Mr. Cranston. All seemed to be in order and he was to have arrived at Jack River at the end of September; indeed I wired Norway House to that effect. Then several delays occurred; first a car accident, and later an attack of dysentery and still further delay. I have a heavy file of letters and telegrams as between Mr. Cranston and myself. By the time he was ready to proceed, passenger boat service from Winnipeg to Norway House had stopped.

The only possible way of reaching Norway House was by way of the Pas, on to Wabowden, the winter route. Of this I advised Mr. Cranston, and on November 6th he wrote to say he was leaving at once, which I presume he did. He said "you will hear from me from Norway House as soon as I get settled. I regret the delay and shall try to make up for it later."

He may have been delayed awaiting freeze up after arriving at Wabowden. I have not heard further from him.

Much time and effort was expended to assure an early arrival of the teacher at Jack River, and the repeated delays have been disturbing, particularly after I had given assurance of his arrival in late September, as a result of which assurance, a number of children and some parents met the boat at the mission dock, but the teacher was not on the boat. I trust he has by this time arrived.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Bishop Dewdney:

Ottawa,
April 13, 1940.

Dear Sir:

I desire to refer to your letter of August 9, 1939, in connection with the Jack River C. E. Combined School.

Since that time we have been in communication with Indian Agent Lazenby regarding this school and it has been found that the average attendance of Indian children in the calendar year 1939 was only 4.58.

This small attendance does not warrant our allowing the school the amount of $650.00 a year and consequently you should inform the Provincial Government authorities that it is our intention to discontinue paying grant at the above rate on June 30, 1940.

After that date if any Indian children attend this school the Department will be prepared to consider allowing a per capita rate of $20.00 a year each based on their average attendance.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Re: Jack River C.E. Indian Day School, No. 519.

From June 1, 1940, it was decided to allow an amount of $175.00 a month toward the salary of the teacher at the above-mentioned school. The Church authorities found it impossible to secure a teacher for the academic year 1940-41, but the school re-opened on October 1, 1941, and has been in continuous operation since that date.

January 1 to June 30, 1942 - 6 months

D.C. Scott, Esq., C.M.G.,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Scott,

Last fall in an interview I had with Mr. Russell T. Ferrier I brought before him the need of a new building for the day school at Jack River, Norway House. This small building was erected more than twenty years ago and has been steadily used for school purposes for the Indians of the Anglican Mission with excellent results. The building is now really unfit for use without considerable expenditure being made upon it which could hardly be justified. This is, I believe, admitted by the Indian Agent and by Mr. Ferrier who has seen the building. Our Missionary Rev. J. F. Marshall has written me asking me to bring the matter before the Department with a view to securing, if possible, immediate action. The school building is on Mission property which is the most convenient location for the children and also for the teacher who is able to board with the Missionary, which is most important especially when, as for some time past, the teacher is a lady. In case any difficulty should arise in the Department putting a school upon Mission property, we would be quite willing to give such rights to the department in respect to the property used for the school as might be necessary.

I may say that I was much impressed when visiting the Mission last August to find practically all the young people able to understand and speak English and I understand this has been largely due to the good work done in the school during the last twenty years.

May I ask your kind consideration to this request. Provision should be made for suitable accommodation for the children when the school re-assembles after the summer vacation, and if this is to be done the work should be put in hand very soon. Should it be decided that a new building cannot be provided this summer, an expenditure of from $75 to $100 will be required to make it usable for next winter.

As I leave shortly to visit Trout Lake, York Factory, and other northern missions and will be away all summer, any communication re this matter should be made to Canon Lofthouse, Kenora, Ont.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

Dear Canon Lofthouse:

I have His Lordship's letter of the 23rd instant, relative to the need of a new building at the Jack River Indian Day School, near Norway House.

I regret to inform you that we were unable to provide for this cause in the appropriation for Indian Education for the current fiscal year. The Superintendent of Indian Education assures me that the Rev. Mr. Marshall has done exceptionally well and should be encouraged, and I shall make a special effort to have funds provided for a new school building next year. It would be advisable for you to arrange for the transfer of a site, in view of the fact that the most convenient location for the school building is on the mission property. This, however, could be attended to when building operations commence. I have noted that the building can be made fairly habitable for another winter by an expenditure of $75.00 or $100.00. I have instructed that favourable consideration be given to any accounts in this connection which are forwarded from the office of Mr. Indian Agent Gordon at Norway House.

July 26th, 1923.

Dear Mr. Scott:

Under date of May 30th, 123-7-5 you wrote me in reference to a proposed new building at the Jack River Indian Day School, near Norway House. While the Department was unable to provide for this cause during the current year, you state that it would be advisable for us to arrange for the transfer of a site as a special effort is to be made to have funds provided for a new school building next year.

I am advised by the Rev. Mr. Marshall that the property of the Jack River Mission was separated from the Indian reserve in 1910 by chief surveyor McLean. In 1916 this property consisting of about 33 acres was surveyed on the request of Mr. Marshall by Mr. Beams, D.L.S. No titles have as yet been granted in that district and we seem to hold the land only as squatters. We have spent considerable money on a splendid Mission House and Church building; would it be possible to secure the title to this property? We should be obliged if you could advise us what steps should be taken to this end, or if there is any possibility of the title being granted. If we held title to the land we should be pleased to arrange transfer of a site for the school building.

Mr. Marshall is anxious to have repairs made to the present school building before another winter. He advises that no local authority has as yet been given for this work to be done, and he cannot proceed with the repairs until Mr. Agent Gordon has been authorized to make the necessary expenditure. Perhaps instructions have gone forward covering this matter; if not it would be encouraging to Mr. Marshall and his work if they could be sent forward as soon as possible, in order that the work may be completed before the school re-opens.

Yours very Faithfully,

MEMO FOR FILE:

His Lordship the Bishop of Keewatin visited the Department today and informed me that the Church Authorities were arranging for title of the mission lot at the Jack River Indian Day School. They are prepared to transfer a site for the new school building, which should be erected early in 1924.

Rev. Mr. Marshall, the Missionary, is, to my personal knowledge, a competent carpenter and builder, and, when arrangements are being made for the new structure, I believe it will be well to have it done by day labour, with him as foreman. Mr. Indian Agent Gordon could purchase the materials and supervise the activity.

Russell T. Ferrier
The Right Reverend
Lord Bishop of Keewatin
Kenora, Ont.

My dear Bishop,-

I am forwarding plans and specifications that I procured from Dr. Fletcher of one of their one-roomed schools, highly recommended and approved by the Manitoba Educational Department.

The best figures I could get on the lumber alone was $1875.00 f.e.b. at Selkirk. The other materials were too jumpy to be able to get a definite estimate, but I was speaking to a contractor who was building the same school with the exception of the porch and who said he only made wages on erecting it for $3000.

I would rather the Indian Department allowed us the privilege of building this school so that we could utilize in the building itself the amount that usually goes as the contractor's profit. We also could use a number of our men, the majority of whom are willing to put in part time gratis if we are given the building of it.

I would also recommend that the foundation be carried down to make a proper basement which could be used as furnace room and place for the children to have their dinner as they are served a hot meal at noon.

If we are allowed to build we could turn in all accounts to the I.D. office so that it could be seen that every dollar was used in the building, as we sorely need the building and would do all in our power to get it. We are now trying to make accommodation for 38 and there are more to come along as soon as the river becomes safe. Dear Mr. Graham:

You will note in the list of school buildings to be erected in the Prairie Provinces that there is an item of $4,000 for a new school at Jack River, in the Norway House agency. Mr. Marshall, can prepare a list of materials that are necessary and arrangements should be made for the purchase and shipment to Jack River as soon as possible. Some of the Indians interested have agreed to give part time gratis to the activity. My dear Mr. Scott:

Dear Mr. Scott:

I have your letter of the 26th ultimo, with reference to the building of the Jack River Day School, quoting an extract from a letter from the Bishop of Keewatin on this subject. I note from this extract that the Bishop objects to Mr. Marshall submitting a price for the work in connection with erection of the building.

It is really disappointing to get such a letter from you. In the first place I am given to understand that utmost economy is to be practiced this year in connection with our building programme and I am given the responsibility of erecting certain buildings; on the list is a Day School at Jack River. Later on you write me under date of May 3rd in connection with this matter as follows:

"The Rev. Mr. Marshall, the local Missionary, is a competent carpenter and builder and he has forwarded to the Department, plans prepared by the Manitoba Dept. of Education."

By the time I received this letter I had already taken action by getting prices from the various lumber Companies, so that there would be no delay. I also had plans on the way to you for approval, which plans were practically the same as the ones later supplied by Mr. Marshall. There is surely no grounds for finding fault here. I objected strongly to Agent Gordon having anything to do with the work for good reasons. I pointed out that I did not know Mr. Marshall and did not feel like taking the responsibility for handing the work over to him without first knowing what the building would cost.

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General of Indian Affairs
OTTAWA.
Was not this wise? How was I to know whether the building under this arrangement might not cost twice as much as it should, leaving it to Mr. Marshall, a man whom I did not know; it was not business. Being a competent carpenter, and as your letters distinctly said he would take over the work as foreman, and knowing that there were none other than Indian workmen at Norway House, I naturally thought he was going to work himself, as it would be absurd to have a man looking on at possibly two Indians or half-breeds working and not taking a hand himself.

Summed up the circumstances are as follows,-

You placed the work of erecting this building in my hands. Later you advise me that Mr. Marshall, the Missionary, is a competent carpenter and that you believed he should be appointed foreman, and Agent Gordon to supervise. I objected to Gordon simply because I know the man's qualifications better than anyone in the Department. Your letter to me would indicate that it was your wish that I should hand the work over to Gordon and Mr. Marshall. I thought this unwise, and still think so. I wanted to find out where we would be in the matter of price and I wrote to Mr. Marshall, and it now turns out that His Lordship objects to Mr. Marshall tendering on the work only; there was no general contract.

If the matter had been left with me, as I think it should have been, I would have sent in a competent man to do the work, who would have had an understanding with me before he left, and had this arrangement been carried out the responsibility would have been placed with me where it was intended it should be, I would have had the building under way, the Bishop would have been satisfied and all would have been well. Is it business to place the responsibility of erecting buildings and then tell me whom I am to employ?

You say it was never contemplated in any instance to ask for tenders for any of these buildings. I understand this, and tenders are not being asked for the buildings. The regulations of the Purchasing Commission are being carried out. Lumber and material is bought after asking all dealers for prices. Plans are shown to carpenters and they give us a price for the completed work. Surely this is in line with regulations. I believe the lumber is now on the ground.

Yours very truly,

MEMORANDUM

Hon. Charles Stewart -

When we decided to erect a new day school building at Jack River for the Anglican Mission, we wrote Rt. Rev. A. D. Dewdney, Bishop of Keewatin, and told him it had been decided to erect the building and that the work would be done under the supervision of the resident missionary, Rev. Mr. Marshall, also that authority would be given to Mr. Agent Gordon to have the building erected.

When we placed all building work in the Western Provinces in Mr. Graham's hands, I sent him a special letter in connection with this matter and told him Mr. Marshall was a competent builder, and might be given the work. Mr. Ferrier, who visited this point two years ago, is able to certify to the ability of Mr. Marshall, who erected his own house, a commodious and comfortable dwelling at the Mission. Mr. Graham did not approve of this as he stated he knows nothing of Mr. Marshall and has no confidence whatever in the Indian Agent. However he asked Mr. Marshall for a tender for the work, but Bishop Dewdney happened to be at Jack Head at the time and would not allow Mr. Marshall to go into competition with regular contractors. The Bishop writes me under date of June 17th, stating:

"The more important question has to do with the request which the Commissioner has made of the Rev. Mr. Marshall to submit a tender in competition with regular contractors. Mr. Marshall is not in a position to submit such a tender, nor am I prepared..."
to permit him to take the position of a contractor. He is a missionary, whose practical ability and experience as a builder is well known. He knows the conditions. He wants the school to be well built and that all the money spent in connection with it shall go into the building. There will be no contractor's profits to be provided for, nor the cost of bringing in outside labour. Native help can be used in a way an outside contractor could not use it and the Indians would have work provided them in a slack season. The Mission also has equipment such as barge, horses, etc., used in the erection of our own buildings which would be available if Mr. Marshall erects the building.

I find that His Lordship in anticipation of Mr. Marshall doing this work had sent in a student to assist him. Mr. Graham has purchased and sent in the lumber and I think under the circumstances as the Bishop has made these arrangements that we should allow Mr. Marshall to erect the building. The point is so remote, being north of Norway House on Lake Winnipeg, neither Mr. Graham nor any of his Inspectors can give personal supervision.

Deputy Superintendent General.
Ottawa, Ontario,
July 9, 1924.

DR. SCOTT

Ref. your memo July 8 with regard to the new day school building at Jack River for the Anglican Mission -

I agree with the proposal contained in your memorandum and I think it would be well for you to write Comr. Graham and suggest to him that the work be done under the supervision of the resident missionary, Rev. Mr. Marshall.

Dear Mr. Bunn:

I received your letter of June 7th and the material for the school building has come to hand by degrees. We have unloaded it and carefully piled it. The cement we have placed well under cover on the site. The plaster material, since it will be some time before it is needed, we have put into our shed, together with the windows and doors and other hardware. We have the old school building ripped down and everything ready to start as soon as we get word to go ahead. As you are well in touch with circumstances and conditions around this part you will understand that sand will be needed for the foundations, and our nearest sand is eight miles away. We have a barge belonging to the Mission and we are hauling sand this week to put under the old school which we intend to erect and use as a parish hall. If we had word as to what the Commissioner intends to do we could have hauled sand for the school foundations but since he has allowed things to go so late into the season, having time will be coming on and we will be using the barge and horses at the hay meadows. As you are aware, but as others are not, there are only the Indian Agent's barge and our own in this part of the country, and the Agent's barge is at work every day getting in cordwood when the weather permits. Most of our men will be back at the end of this month as fishing has been very poor and the fish companies are shutting down. We could utilize the work of these men who are good carpenters under supervision in helping to push on the erection of the school. I do not understand the ball-up on this school affair. We had instructions from the Superintendent, Mr. Duncan Scott in a letter to the Bishop to go ahead with this work using our Indians and with myself looking after the work. Then on the same mail we had another from Ottawa saying that the matter had been referred to Commissioner Graham, and on the following mail we had one from Commissioner Graham asking me to submit tenders for the labour. As you know, that would be an impossibility for me, breaking both the rules of the Church and those laid down for men working in the Indian field, but as was stated to Mr. Scott by the Bishop, I was perfectly willing and am yet to carry on the work under the former plan of day labour, thereby giving our own men the benefit of the employment and also saving the Department a considerable amount of expenses of higher paid men brought in from outside.
In regard to the building, the plans were changed and there was no provision made for the excavation of a basement. We have a team here at the Mission which could take out sufficient for the furnace room, though the plans submitted call for a basement under the whole school which was to be used for the children getting their dinner as we supply them with a hot meal at noon, the cooking being done in our own house. This was to save dirtying up the school-room but as it would be useless to try and present the matter at the present time to the Commissioner, I made the offer to you by the Doctor that we take out sufficient earth to make a furnace room and this would save in the heating plant by putting in a pipeless furnace in the basement. I have made enquiry from every teacher coming in here in the last two years re the heater in the schoolroom and they have all said that they see an absolute failure. One staying here at the present time from a consolidated school west of Winnipeg says that they see ripping them out and putting a furnace plant in the basement. This was a school built only five years ago. You cannot force heat down.

As you know, the season here is getting on, and I would like you to look into these matters as I am almost sure that the Commissioner at Regina has overlooked or forgotten us altogether. I am awaiting his reply before writing to him again. I answered his letter in June and I judge that he might think it impertinent if I were to write him again.

I know that you have our welfare at heart and I can trust you to do your best for us in the matter. If anything important turns up, if you telephone to Col. Stevenson of the Forestry Department he would send a message through by wireless.

Yours faithfully,

John F. J. Marshall

My Lord:-

I have your letter of the 28th ultimo, regarding the erection of a school at Jack River, Norway House, Manitoba.

I exceedingly regret that there has been a mix-up over this matter.

I received instructions from the Deputy Superintendent General informing me that it was the intention to erect a Day School at Jack River, and instructing me to proceed with the work. In this letter he mentioned the fact that Mr. Marshall would be willing to undertake the supervision of the work.

I had a certain amount of money allowed for this particular school. I bought the material after getting quotations from the various lumber dealers in Winnipeg and Selkirk. This material was shipped on my instructions to Norway House and addressed to Rev. Mr. Marshall. I wrote to Mr. Marshall with the intention of finding out what the actual labour on such a building would cost. Unfortunately the word "contract" was used in the letter. He replied to my letter saying he could not undertake any contract but that he would supervise the work.

We have in our employ competent foremen builders; men who are capable of building anything in that line, and it was my intention from the beginning to send one of these men up to do the work. It is still my intention to do this and I can assure you that the work will be completed in a workmanlike manner before cold weather sets in.

I regret that there has been a mix-up in this matter, but it is through no fault of mine whatever. I do not know Mr. Marshall personally and I do not feel that I could send a competent builder up there and ask him to take instructions from Mr. Marshall, in view of the fact that these men are entrusted here with responsibilities five and ten times as great as the work that we are to do at Norway House.

I can assure you that the interests of the school will be well looked after and hope that you have not been caused any very great inconvenience.

Yours very truly,

(Sgd) W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

My dear Mr. Scott,-

As things have proceeded the season is half gone and so far, until I received the Commissioner's letter today, we received no word, official or unofficial, as to what was to be done, leaving us in uncertainty but with financial obligations incurred in good faith, I consider that in some way or other compensation should be given to Mr. Marshall so that some part if not all of the cost involved in the engagement of this assistant should be provided. It is not fair that they should be out of pocket or that the Church should be out of pocket in trying to carry out efficiently the plans of the Indian Department. Dear Mr. Scott:-

I am in receipt of a long letter from His Lordship, the Bishop of Keewatin, with regard to the building of the Day School at Jack River, Norway House Agency.

The Bishop is undoubtedly under the impression that this work was going to be handed over to the Rev. J.F.J. Marshall, his missionary at that point, and is naturally disappointed with the action I took in the matter. The Department are entirely to blame for giving such an impression to His Lordship, as I was given to understand that there was so much money set aside for the building of this school and the work was placed in my hands. It is true you mentioned that Mr. Marshall was up there, and that he was capable of doing the work and willing to undertake it. I did not know anything about Mr. Marshall; I do not know anything about him today. He might possibly be only a handy man or he might be an experienced builder. However, in view of your letter stating that he was up there I took the matter of building up with him and asked him what he would charge to perform the labour, we to supply the material. This was necessary in order to get competitive prices and to know what the building would cost before we started operations. It appears that this did not meet with the approval of His Lordship the Bishop, or Mr. Marshall.

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Was it your idea that I should let this work go to a man I did not know, who could not even tell me beforehand what the building was going to cost, or where the cost would end. As a matter of fact, Mr. Marshall did not intend to do the work himself.

Might I ask what was the idea of placing the work in my hands if it was not for the purpose of curtailing expenses, and how can expenses be curtailed if the work is taken out of my hands?

We have had several examples of late where the recommendations of the church authorities to the Government have been acted upon and have been very costly. I quote you the stables at Round Lake and at Portage la Prairie, both of which would have been built had I not advised against it. The extravagance practised in connection with the barn at the Edmonton School. This should show the Department that it should have some control over expenditures instead of leaving it to the church authorities, who are very often impractical.

I might say that I cannot carry on under existing conditions, nor can economy be practised if I have no control. I am criticized by the church authorities, as I told you some time ago I would be, simply because you place me in the awkward positions that you do.

Only a few minutes ago I received a telegram from you asking what arrangement I had made for the painting at Fort Alexander School, and stating that if nothing had been done you would take the necessary action. What position am I in regard to this particular matter? I get the work started and then it is taken out of my hands, for what reason I do not know.

In connection with this matter I would draw your attention to the fact that on the 2nd of June, letter #125-1-5 you informed me that only the exterior of the main building of this school was to be painted this year. On the 5th of June you reiterated these instructions. Before I undertook the work I sent Inspector Christianson up to Fort Alexander to make an examination of the building, as I did not feel like incurring expenditure without having first hand knowledge as to what was required. I was not surprised to get a report from the Inspector, saying that
the main building had only recently been painted and was in good shape. He said, however, that some of the outbuildings might be painted at a cost of $200.00, and some interior work at a cost of $300.00. This work not being mentioned in your letter to me, and in view of your previous instructions to me that you only intended to paint the exterior of the main building, I did not proceed with the work further, but wrote to you fully on the 23rd of June asking for instructions at once. To this day, August 5th, I have not even received a reply to this important letter, but I might say that I was somewhat surprised to receive your telegram this morning above referred to, taking the work out of my hands, for what reason I do not understand.

When I was in Ottawa the Minister assured me that all this kind of work was going to be left for me to deal with, but you seem to be of a different opinion. It was only last week that the Minister reiterated the instructions that he gave me in Ottawa.

I think there should be a thorough understanding now, as no business can be carried on successfully and be mixed up in this way.

It appears from the actions of the Department that they have no desire to assist me, but rather to complicate matters by bringing in outsiders whose advice is taken before that of your own officer.

Yours very truly,

Dear Mr. Scott:

I am enclosing a file of correspondence re Jack River Day School which, if you have a little time to read it, will give you some idea of the way things are being done and some of the difficulties in connection with the erection of it.

When this matter was first taken up between the Bishop of Keewatin and yourself, there were a number of things taken into consideration which I have reason to believe have not been passed on to Commissioner Graham or are being completely ignored by him.

I am not ignorant of the difficulties between Ottawa and Regina but do not see why we should be made the bone of contention as it is easily to be seen in the hospital that is being erected at Norway House and the way we are being left without a school which should have been ready by Sept. 1st. We have already taken down the old one to clear the site for the new. We have maintained a school here for twenty-five years and asked nothing towards upkeep and as soon as we ask for a grant or a new one (which met with your approval and which we appreciated very much and which only means an outlay of four or five thousand dollars) our whole proposition is turned down, but when the school at Gross Lake want about thirty-five thousand, the whole contract is handed over to them without even a government inspector.

After spending fifteen years working with these people and always upholding the government to them as being right, and in assisting in every way possible the Indian and other Departments, one's confidence is broken by such treatment. I am not sore; I am beyond that but it makes one wonder if the Indian Department cares at all for the people who are doing the actual work among them.

Our plans which you approved of and which others rejected have not even been returned and I am responsible for them to the Manitoba Educational Department. There has been no provision made in the new plans for a basement which was to be used for a
furnace and a place where the children could have their dinner. (This is a hot meal prepared and provided at the Mission, not a lunch.) We had promised to have the excavation taken out by our own team, which is already done, but on the order are only seventy-five bags of cement, sufficient only for a floating foundation which you will note in my letter to Mr. Bunn.

I was not asking for the erection of this school to be given into our hands for personal gain but that our people might have the benefit and experience; but all government seems to be given into the hands of outsiders and some not desirable citizens, foreigners, and the Missions and the Hudson's Bay Co. are the only ones who use native labour when building. A good many of our men were willing to give two days each gratis, and then again what is the use of Missions teaching our younger ones carpentry, when, as they say themselves, when there is a board building to be erected they do not get a chance to hammer a nail.

There are privileges enjoyed among ourselves which cannot be obtained by money and which go a great way towards keeping an isolated community together. At the present time I am using the Hudson's Bay Manager's gasoline boat for towing the barge and have hauled some sand expecting to continue with the building. I cannot use this boat to haul sand for a contractor.

As you will see in Mr. Bunn's letter I am asked to see that all material is cared for, and Commissioner Graham states in his that he would be glad if I hauled the sand to the site, but in neither letter is mentioned where I am to get the money from to pay for this work. Up to the present I have carried out as far as I can their requests but I have come to the end of my own resources.
