Dear Mr. Bunn:

I received your letter of June 7th and the material for the school building has come to hand by degrees. We have unloaded it and carefully piled it. The cement we have placed well under cover on the site. The plaster material, since it will be some time before it is needed, we have put into our shed, together with the windows and doors and other hardware. We have the old school building ripped down and everything ready to start as soon as we get word to go ahead. As you are well in touch with circumstances and conditions around this part, you will understand that sand will be needed for the foundations; and our nearest sand is eight miles away. We have a barge belonging to the Mission and we are hauling sand this week to put under the old school which we intend to re-erect and use as a parish hall. If we had had word as to what the Commissioner intends to do, we could have hauled sand for the school foundations; but since he has allowed things to go so late into the season, having time will be coming on and we will be using the barge and horses at the hay meadows. As you are aware, but as others are not, there are only the Indian Agent's barge and our own in this part of the country; and the Agent's barge is at work every day getting in cordwood when the weather permits. Most of our men will be back at the end of this month as fishing has been very poor and the fish companies are shutting down. We could utilize the work of these men, who are good carpenters under supervision, in helping to push on the erection of the school. I do not understand the ball-up on this school affair. We had instructions from the Superintendent, Mr. Duncan Scott in a letter to the Bishop to go ahead with this work, using our Indians and with myself looking after the work. Then on the same mail we had a letter from Ottawa saying that the matter had been referred to Commissioner Graham, and on the following mail we had one from Commissioner Graham asking me to submit tenders for the labour. As you know, that would be an impossibility for me, breaking both the rules of the Church and those laid down for men working in the Indian field, but as was stated to Mr Scott by the Bishop, I was perfectly willing and am yet to carry on the work under the former plan of day labour, thereby giving our own
men the benefit of the employment; and also saving the Department a considerable amount in the expenses of higher paid men brought in from outside.

In regard to the building, the plans were changed and there was no provision made for the excavation of a basement. We have a team here at the Mission which could take out sufficient earth for the furnace room, though the plans submitted call for a basement under the whole school which was to be used for the children getting their dinner, as we supply them with a hot meal at noon; the cooking being done in our own house. This was to save dirtying up the school room but as it would be useless to try and present the matter at the present time to the Commissioner, I made the offer to you by the Doctor that we take out sufficient earth to make a furnace room and this would save in the heating plant by putting in a pipeless furnace in the basement. I have made enquiry from every teacher coming in here in the last two years re the heater in the schoolroom and they have all said that they are an absolute failure. One staying here at the present time from a consolidated school near Winnipeg says that they are ripping them out and putting a furnace plant in the basement. This was a school built only five years ago. You cannot force heat down.

As you know, the season here is getting on, and I would like you to look into these matters as I am almost sure that the Commissioner at Regina has overlooked or forgotten us altogether. I am awaiting his reply before writing him again. I answered his letter in June and I judge that he might think it impertinent if I were to write him again.

I know that you have our welfare at heart and I can trust you to do your best for us in the matter. If anything important turns up, if you telephone to Colonel Stevenson of the Forestry Department he would send a message through by wireless.

Yours faithfully,

(Signed) J.F.J. Marshall,

Dear Sir:-

Mr. Bunn has forwarded me your letter of the 16th of July addressed to him with regard to the school that it is proposed to build at Norway House; and in reply I may say that the building programme is not late, and so far as Norway House School is concerned, is not being lost sight of.

In a short time one of our building foremen will proceed to Norway House with the idea of erecting this building. In the meantime I would be glad if you would have sufficient sand brought to the site, so that there will be no time lost after the foreman arrives on the spot. He will take from here one man and possibly engage a couple of others if he can do so; the building to be completed in every respect before he leaves.

Yours truly,

Rev. John F.J. Marshall,

Dear Mr. Dunn:

An enclosing copy of letter received August 3rd, mail received by the fishing tug Carry. Some people fully understand conditions and school will be open September 1st.

We already have excavated for basement. In the excavation there is solid rock that is 6" from ground level running at right angles to the back wall for a distance of 12', and on the west end at 40' from the other rock, there is rock from 18" to 2' from surface. Both of these rocks can be used for wall. I have tested the other parts with 5' auger and in places can get down from 3' to 5' with good outlet for drain. I should like to suggest that we make use of this to make almost a full basement so that we could have a proper place for the children to have their dinner. If you will recall the order, there are only 75 bags of cement and would judge that they had in view what is commonly called a floating foundation, and with a little extra cost for more cement we could have the foundation to rock on almost all four sides, which is greatly needed in this country owing to the heaving of the ground.

As you will see by the enclosed copy the Commissioner would be glad if we hauled sufficient sand to the site. We can get the sand from the banks of Sandy Islands but he does not state a word about other banks we might draw on to pay the men and up to the present have paid from my own account for work already done, but do not feel like risking too much nor have I the funds to continue. I have appealed to Mr. Gordon for funds even for the unloading expenses and he stated that there were no instructions to pay out for the above work, nor had he the money on hand to do it.

I have already saved the Department over one hundred dollars by using a little judgment, taking advantage of the wind, which had been blowing for three days and had raised the water sufficiently, to float the Northern Fish Co.'s freight boat to the rocks close to the school site. The water had not been as high in the last four years as it was those three days. The captain would not believe it until I went out in a skiff and measured the depth. At the present time one could scarcely float a canoe in the same place. The material if landed at our dock which is 16' long would have to be carried by man power to the land and tanned afterwards to the school site, which of course some had to be as it was landed at the dock on other trips but the bulk of the material happened to be on the day of high water.

Mr. Commissioner Graham:

Dear Sir:

We were very glad indeed to have Mr. George and Mr. Wilson with us while building the school.

The building is now complete, looks well and have done everything possible to make it warm in this climate. They were both very competent and conscientious in their work and have rendered every assistance possible.

Yours faithfully,

(Signed) John F. Marshall.
Sir:

Referring to your letter of August 15th last, introducing Mr. Henry George, I may say that I regret that I have been unable to render any material assistance to Mr. George, as the distance between the Agency and Jack River Mission, while not great, is considerable by our method of travelling. I did, however, send my boat to assist in hauling some sand.

I may say that I have seen the school today, and consider it a very suitable and satisfactory building. The basement and furnace have added much to the convenience and comfort over what was provided in the original plans. I was surprised to find it so nearly finished.

Mr. George, I consider has done good work, and has pushed the work with energy, in the face of bad and unfavorable weather.

Rev. Mr. Marshall, the missionary, has also done a great deal of work, in preparing for the building, handling and providing material, excavating, securing men to assist and working himself on the job.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Mr. Scott,

I wish to bring to your attention the fact that the day school at Jack River is completed in every detail and is now ready for occupancy.

I would point out that Mr. Henry George, our building foreman left Winnipeg on the 18th of August to start this job, and he was back in the City of Regina on the 16th of September. Taking from this six days for travelling up and down, he completed the whole job in three weeks time, including the installation of the furnace. Mr. George carried back with him letters from the Agent and the Missionary, copies of which I am enclosing herewith.

I may say for your information that the Rev. Mr. Marshall, who is a handy man, was employed by Mr. George as a carpenter on this job and was paid for his work by Mr. George. He may, however, have some little bill against the Department for handling material before Mr. George arrived.

This building was kept within the amount authorized.

Yours very truly,

Sir:

In August, last, you purchased a quantity of Duroplate blackboard, with chalk trough and moulding, for the use of two schools in the Norway House Agency. Accounts for this material in favour of T. A. Thorburn Co. Ltd., Winnipeg, were forwarded as per your vouchers No. 3038 and No. 3039. Voucher No. 3039 to the amount of $54.82 is for blackboard material for the use of the Jack River Indian Day School, and voucher No. 3038 for an equal amount has also been paid. I shall be pleased if you will state what school the blackboard material on this latter voucher was sent to. As both vouchers are for the same amount, it is difficult to decide whether they are duplicates or for material supplied to two different schools.

Your early reply will oblige,

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, Ont.

Sir:-

Re Duro-plate Blackboard.

I have your letter, number and date as given above.

Re Vouchers #3038 and 3039, these are for two lots, and both went to Jack River Day School.

The first lot was ordered on the 21st of August from Messrs T.A. Thorburn Co., and then on the 23rd I received a letter from the Rev'd J.F. Marshall, re Black-board, which is as follows:-

"Also more blackboard, Mr. George says he will need more blackboard, as he only figured for the front of the room and will require some for the side. 3 x 8' lts."

On receipt of this I duplicated the order, and that is how the two vouchers are the same. I got both orders on the same boat.

Mr. George was the foreman who figured out the quantities of the materials, and I accepted his requisitions for any materials, and submitted vouchers accordingly.

I hope this will clear up this matter.

I have the honor to be,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Dec. 8, 1924.

Right Reverend
Lord Bishop of Keewatin,
Kenora, Ont.

My dear Bishop,

Having been delayed in getting out the following statement, I have made the same act in itemized form giving date of work and hours of labour.

The Work and Time sheet includes the work of eight different Indians, the labour being done when it was possible to get these men and weather permitting. The last item is my own time for actual work done at the school while these men were under my supervision.

Item 9 on the statement is gasoline bill enclosed. This gasoline was used on the gasoline boat when towing sand.

Item 10 is cement that was borrowed from us which we had for our own use, and which when replaced would
be too late for us twice and am therefore sending Mr. Nooker's bill and freight account item. And ten are charged in my own account and therefore responsible for paying them.

It was fortunate we had the cement on hand as it took considerably more than had been figured on the estimates owing to the size of wall and thickness having to be increased to get a footing on account of the rock.

Now as to student expense, I may say board in this country is high, even the people who keep the inn are not making as much as expected at $3.00 per day and we have charged him $2.50 a meal which only covers the food and are making no charge for lodging.

I think all the other items explain themselves and may state here we have made no charge for use of barges, gasoline boat or other equipment that was used in connection with the building of the school.

All of which I have the honour to submit.

I am sir,

Your obedient servant,
John F. J. Marshall
Bishopstowe
KENORA, ONT.
December 20th, 1924.

Duncan C. Scott, Esq., C.M.G.,
Deputy Supt. General, Ind. Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Dr. Scott,

I have just received from the Rev. J.F.J. Marshall, Jack River, Norway House, the enclosed statement of costs incurred by him in connection with the erection of the new school at that point. The explanations given in the covering letter to me which I am enclosing will, I think, be ample for the purpose. If you should desire any further explanations I shall be pleased to do my best to provide the same.

I hope you will expedite the payment of the account as Mr. Marshall has advanced payments made for labour, etc., and has had to overdraw his account in the Diocese. The student also has only received a portion of the amount to which he is entitled for his summer's work, and I would again remind you of our correspondence in that connection.

Awaiting your kind attention,

Believe me,

Most faithfully yours,

A.D. Keewatin

February 8th, 1927.

Russell T. Ferrier, Esq.,
Supt. of Indian Education,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

The Rev. W. H. J. Walter, the missionary in charge of the Anglican Mission at Jack River, Norway House, has recently written to us in reference to the Day School at Jack River.

For a number of years the former missionary, the Rev. J. F. J. Marshall provided a hot meal for the children of the school at midday on each school day. This has been of great benefit to the children, according to testimony received during the incumbency of Mr. Marshall, and as seen in the good health of the children.

The Rev. W. H. J. Walter now writes, stating "it is necessary for the children to have something hot at midday", but, "he cannot afford to feed these children".

The grants from the Department of Indian Affairs and the Department of Education of the Province of Manitoba are paid in full as salary to Miss Bagshaw, the teacher, and the Rev. W. H. J. Walter and his wife, on their limited income, have thus far, provided and cooked the meal as above.

Would it be possible for the Department to make an additional grant of $100.00 per year to the Jack River school for the purpose of providing this midday meal for the children, thus making the annual grant $750.00, this additional $100.00 to be paid by us to the missionary?

As the matter stands at present, the missionary receives nothing whatever from the Department, and it is obvious that he cannot be expected to provide the "necessary" meal as above unless some financial provision can be made.

Trusting this will receive your favourable consideration,

Yours respectfully,

[Signature]

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6237, file 519-5, part 1)
Ottawa, February 16, 1927.

Very Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 8th instant, relative to the providing of a midday meal to the pupils of the Jack River Anglican Indian Day School and requesting that the Department make a grant of $100 per year for this purpose.

In reply I have to say that the Department will instruct the local Indian Agent, Mr. Wm. Gordon, at Norway House, to supply the teacher with the necessary food supplies for the serving of the meal. We prefer to have the agent arrange for the purchase of these supplies rather than to make an additional grant towards the teacher's salary, as requested by you. The agent will be informed that he may incur an expenditure during each teaching year for the purpose of purchasing the supplies necessary to an amount not exceeding $100.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Very Rev. Canon J. L. Boffhouse,
Synod Office,
Kenora, Ont.
Ottawa, February 16, 1927.

Sir:

A request has been received from the church authorities under whose auspices the Jack River Anglican Indian Day School is conducted that a hot meal at midday be provided to the pupils. We understand that the teacher and the wife of the missionary, with the assistance of the older girls in the school, will arrange to prepare and serve the meal.

I have, therefore, to request that you will arrange to purchase and forward as soon as possible the supplies necessary for the midday meal, such as tea, sugar, coconuts, condensed milk, beans, rice, salt, etc. The Department will approve of a total expenditure for the purpose not exceeding $100 for the period from March 1, 1927, to March 1, 1928. You may have the supplies forwarded from time to time - it being considered that a few months' provisions at a time would be satisfactory.

Please forward properly certified accounts covering the expenditure incurred after each purchase by you at various times during the year. Should any utensils be required by the teacher in the preparation and serving of this midday meal, you may also arrange for their purchase and delivery. The Department will rely on you to see that no unnecessary expense is incurred. I have to request that you will have the first shipment of the above mentioned supplies forwarded as soon as possible.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Sir:

As a consequence there will be no change on the Department for the June Quarter for issues to the children of this Day School.

I have received a letter in reply to mine passing on the information to Mr. Walter, and I am pleased to forward a copy of the contents. It is pleasing when Mission workers appreciate the co-operation of the Department, and when the said workers are willing to co-operate with the Department in any help to the Indian people. The following is a copy of Mr. Walter's letter:

"Dear Mr. Gordon,

I received your letter re stopping the allowance for meals for the school at the end of March. We are sorry, of course, but we would like you to convey to the Indian Department our thanks for the help that we have received in this way since we have been here. I have always found the Department very generous and common gratitude compels me to write this letter to you. Mrs. Walter and I have talked it over and have decided to give a meal of some sort as we have been doing.

Again thanking you

I remain,
Yours truly,

W. H. J. Walter."

Dear Dr. McGill:

I beg to submit a report on the Jack River Church of England Indian Day School, visited August 9th, 1933.

Mrs. E. Gall is the teacher in charge, and holds her second class permanent certificate.

There are forty-two children enrolled but the attendance is very poor. I would refer the Department to Mr. Dunlop's report in connection with attendance.

The interior wall of the school is very dirty. It was erected some nine years ago, and no interior decoration has yet been carried out. The school is also badly in need of exterior painting. The original coat of paint has almost entirely disappeared. The blackboard is badly pitted and should be repainted. This repair should be carried out this fall if at all possible.

The building is heated by a furnace in the basement, and I understand the building is quite comfortable. Biscuits and soup are served the children at noon.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

I beg to report that on the 17th instant I inspected the Roman Catholic Indian Day School on the Jack River.

There are 15 pupils on the roll at this school, 7 of whom are non-treaty, and the average attendance is fair.

The pupils were all very clean and well clothed.

The teacher, Reverend Sister St Patrick, is new to the work among Indian children, but is very keenly interested in it and is doing well. The discipline was very good indeed.

The school building was perfectly clean in every part, and all the equipment well cared for.

During the summer of 1934 a new dormitory was completed in the upper floor of the building, with the idea of having resident pupils, and the Principal, Rev; Albert Chamberland O.M.I. requests the approval of the Department to the use of this dormitory, and thus making this school into a Residential School.

For the better information of the Department, I am attaching hereto a rough sketch of a cross section, and the floor lay-out of the dormitory in question. The area of the floor, excluding the dormer windows, of which there are four, is 27'-0" X 38'-0" and the height of the ceiling is from 31'-0" at the walls, sloping up to 7'-0" as the maximum height.

The Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa Ont.;
There are 13 beds installed in this dormitory at the present time, but I understand that the idea is to have 20 beds eventually.

There is a toilet built into the wall near the stairs, which is a very small place, being no larger than a fair sized packing box. There is a small ventilator installed in the ceiling of the toilet, leading to the outside through the roof.

I may say that I have been discussing this matter with Dr Turpel, and he expresses the opinion that there is not sufficient space in this dormitory to accommodate 20 pupils and keep the air in it as fresh as it should be kept, especially when the tendency of these Indian children to T.B. is taken into consideration.

I should be glad if the Department would advise me of its opinion in regard to this dormitory.

Your obedient Servant,

P.G. Lazenby
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, February 11, 1935.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 21st ultimo, reporting on your inspection of the Jack River R. C. Indian Day School and enclosing a sketch of a dormitory that was contemplated to be built on the upper floor of the building, with the idea of having resident pupils. The Department is pleased to note that the day school is making progress and that the building is in good condition and all equipment well cared for.

Regarding the new dormitory, I would say that, from the information and sketch which you forwarded, the Department is not favorably disposed to the use of same as sleeping accommodation for Indian children as there is considerable fire hazard. Please furnish further particulars regarding the stairway leading up to the dormitory and state if you consider same to be satisfactory in allowing the pupils easy access to and from the dormitory. You should also furnish full particulars as to the fire escape arrangements. It is noted from the sketch that there are double doors leading to a platform, with pole fire escape.

From the dimensions given of the dormitory, it is noted that there would be air space available for approximately ten pupils. In the event of the dormitory being used, it is doubtful if the Department would have any funds to provide a grant towards the maintenance of any number in excess of the present number for the children attending the residential school at that point. As you may be aware, the Department provides a per capita grant for 30 pupils, approximately 10 of whom are at Gross Lake and 20 at Jack River.

I shall be pleased to have your opinion regarding the suitability of the dormitory on the upper floor of the day school building from a health standpoint, also regarding the fire hazard and fire escape arrangements.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

28th February 1935.

Sir,

I beg to report that today I visited the Jack River R.C. Indian Day School, and made another inspection of this school, particularly in connection with the new dormitory, in accordance with instructions contained in your letter No; 123-10-5 of the 11th instant.

The whole school throughout, was in very clean and orderly condition. There were 29 pupils present in the classroom, all clean and well clothed, 22 of whom were in residence in the building. The classroom register was marked up to date.

With regard to the stairway leading up to the new dormitory from the floor below, I beg to say that this is a 'closed' stair well in the upper half. The distance between the walls of this stair well, is but 27 inches, with the stairs between, which is extremely narrow of course. There are 15 steps, the lowest three or four turning at a right angle into the corridor of the floor below the dormitory. The ceiling of the dormitory is only about 5' 4" above the top step of the stairs, so that a grown person must stoop down when going on to the stairs from the dormitory, in order to avoid knocking the head against the ceiling. After descending two or three steps however, one can walk upright the rest of the way down the stairs. If there were 20 pupils sleeping in this dormitory, (as requested by the Principal), and a fire should occur in such a way as to block access to the fire escape pole, these stairs would, in my opinion, prove very inadequate to evacuate the pupils from the dormitory, especially if any panic should occur.

With regard to the fire escape arrangements,

The Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa Ont;

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6237, file 520-5, part 1)
as shown on the sketch I forwarded with my letter of the 21st January last, there is a double door at one end of the dormitory in question, which leads on to a small platform. There is a hole in this platform, through which there is a 1½ inch pipe pole, descending to a similar platform at the floor below, from which there is a 2 inch pipe pole to the ground. At the time of my January inspection of this school, the double doors leading from the top (new) dormitory to the fire escape platform, were frozen so that they could not have been opened in case of a fire, excepting with the use of an axe. These doors were frozen again today, but not so badly, as they were opened with a little extra exertion. Both the Principal and the Sister Superior informed me that the pupils are all adept in sliding down the fire escape poles, using them as means of reaching the ground at any time, instead of going down the stairs.

There are three hand fire extinguishers, of about 2½ gallon capacity, in the building, one in the basement, one in the kitchen, and one on the first floor. There is no extinguisher on the floor where the new dormitory is located. There should be, I consider, at least two more extinguishers of 2½ gallon capacity, and about 6 small ones on the walls of this building, located in various easily reached positions, as there is no water system for fire protection. The risk of fire from the chimneys is, I consider, very small. There are but two chimneys; one from the kitchen and one from the fires in the boiler room. Both chimneys are well built of stone and brick, and both are located outside of the building.

Considering the new dormitory from the standpoint of the health of the pupils, I cannot think that it is suitable, owing to its very low ceiling, and the great tendency of these children to Tuberculosis. I may say also, that I have consulted with Dr Turpel, and he agrees with me in this. There are 13 beds in this dormitory at the present time.

I may mention that the Reverend Principal informed me.
informed me, while discussing the matter of this new dormitory today, that last year, the Department had promised the Rev. Father Lajeunesse, that the grant for this school would be increased, if a new dormitory were provided to accommodate additional pupils.

I am attaching hereto, a rough sketch, which shows the fire escape poles to reach the ground from the new dormitory.

Your obedient Servant,

P.G. Laßenby
Indian Agent.

THIS LETTER HAS BEEN SENT OTTAWA 17th January 1935

Sir,

In reference to the Return from the Lake Manitoba School for September Quarter last I beg to say that upon examining the same it is found that the average attendance is computed as the Department requires. By Rule 10 the average attendance is found by dividing the total number of days attendance of all the pupils by the number of school days in the Quarter and by Rule 5 all authorized holidays are allowed and will be paid for. The number of school days in the Quarter was 65,- School open 40 days, authorized holidays 25, aggregate attendance 197,- deducting the 25 authorized holidays from the 65 days in the Quarter leaves 40 school days, which divided into 197 gives 4.92 average for the Quarter. The Department would like you to see that the average is calculated in this manner by the teachers of all schools in your Superintendency.

As the wording of Rules 5 and 10 is somewhat conflicting it will be changed so that no doubt may exist as to what is meant by the average attendance for the Quarter.

Your obedient servant,

H. McColl, Esq:

I first visited the Lake Manitoba School on the 8th of July, 1897; the attendance was very small, and the children backward in their work. Miss Goulet was acting as teacher for her Father. The explanation given by the teacher for the condition of affairs was that the School was disorganized at the time owing to the removal from the old school building to the new. The explanation appeared reasonable. The following day I met the Indians in Council and they complained of the School not being satisfactory. I also noticed that the relations between the Indians and Miss Goulet were not very friendly.

My next visit was on the 5th of Aug., 1898; the attendance on this occasion was 20 with an average for the previous quarter of 16.84/100. The School work was under the charge of the Misses Goulet, and was an improvement on the previous year, but still left room for much criticism. The Indians had no complaints to make, and nothing was said by them in regard to the School.

The past year I visited the School on the 19th of Aug., and was informed by Mr. Goulet, after waiting some time, that he could not get the children together, and he informed me that there had been no school for some time as the parents would not send the children. The attendance for the previous quarter as per the returns was 5.60/100. I requested Mr. Goulet to let me see the School register, and he informed me that it was not in the School but thought it was in the Church. He further stated that he was completely discouraged and wished to resign.
the Indians were not friendly to him and would not send their children to the school, I informed him that I thought it was the best thing to do under the circumstances and suggested to him that he might send it in to me to take effect as he might desire, at the end of the Sep't or December quarter, later in the day I met the Indians in Council, I spoke to them about the condition of the school, and lack of attendance, an answer one of the Councillors stated that when they sent their children there was no teacher at the school, Mr. Coulet in reply stated that there was no use in going to the school when they would not send their children, I informed the Indians that if they did not send their children that I would recommend the Department to close the school as it was useless to provide a teacher in they did not take sufficient interest to send their children, I further told them to start sending them at once and Mr. Coulet or some other teacher would be on hand to teach them, their reply was that they wanted an English Teacher and that Mr. Coulet did not teach the children properly, I told them that the matter of a teacher was largely in the hands of the Church and that they should know best the kind of teacher required, I further told them that Mr. Coulet intended to resign shortly, and at his request I asked them to treat him and his family kindly, and as the winter was approaching to allow him to remain on the reserve if he wished until spring, and render him all the assistance they could.

Memo: Mr. Benson,

The following clipping is taken from Mr. Agent Martineau's report for the year ended 30th June last regarding the school for the Lake Manitoba Band.

Education.—There are thirty-four children of school age. The average attendance is five owing mostly to sicknesses of the pupils and parents taking their children away for the summer with domestics for the purpose of fishing, trapping, hunting, and visiting friends. The school has been kept with a very poor attendance so much so that the teacher has decided to resign, if the Indians do not send their children regularly to school in future; in consequence, the pupils are only advanced to Standard II, and a few in Standard III. The school is of the Roman Catholic denomination. The school-house, which is new, is comfortable for the pupils, and is well supplied with material, books and biscuit. The progress is very slow in many cases. The discipline and behaviour are good.

MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Scott,

With reference to the letter from the Deputy Minister of Education for the Province of Manitoba I beg to say that the Indian reserve to which he refers is known as the Dog Creek Reserve and the Indians living there are part of the Lake Manitoba Band.

They had a school there up to December 31st, 1917, when it was closed for want of a teacher, poor attendance and unsatisfactory accommodation; the building being old and dilapidated and without any provision for living quarters for the teacher. The average attendance dropped to four for the last quarter the school was open and the majority of the Indians live three or four miles from the school.

Last August Mr. Fletcher was informed that the Department was not prepared to re-open the school on this reserve, and that it had no funds available for a building.

Mr. Fletcher, in his letter above referred to, states that the white settlers are about to form a school section and that he understands that there are several half-breed families whose children could attend the school, and he mentions one by the name of Monkman and another named Spence, who are receiving treaty. I could find no trace of Spence on the pay list, but there is a Mrs. Monkman who draws treaty, but she has no children on the list. If a school were established in the locality referred to by Mr. Fletcher it would be of no use to the Indians on the reserve.

We have little or no information about these Indians and I would suggest that, before giving a definite answer to Mr. Fletcher, Mr. Agent Ogletree be asked for a report.

Ottawa, March 23, 1920.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 8th instant tendering your resignation as teacher of the Lake Manitoba (Dog Creek) Indian Day School, to take effect on the first of April, next.

Ottawa, March 23, 1920.

Sir,

I beg to inform you that Mr. Henry Springer, teacher of the Lake Manitoba (Dog Creek) Indian Day School, has tendered his resignation to take effect on the first of April next. He is being informed that his resignation is accepted.

You will be good enough to consult the Roman Catholic Church authorities with a view to obtaining a suitable teacher to begin duties, if possible, upon the reopening of the school after the Easter holidays. The name, age, qualifications and experience of the teacher nominated for this school should be forwarded for the consideration of the Department.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

J.D. McLean
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Now, as he is married and his wife has been teaching previously for many years, no doubt he would carry out his promises, he would give complete satisfaction. As there is no more opposition from the part of the Indians, consequently, I recommend him and I ask you to appoint him at once, teacher of the Dog Creek Indian Reserve School, as Mr. H. S. Springer has resigned at the end of March.

Now, the question of a residence for the teacher has not been solved yet, although you promised to do so, as per your letter No. 116758/1, you must understand it is almost impossible for me to find a reliable teacher, if he has to take his residence in a corner of the school house, as did Mr. H. Springer last winter, especially if he is married and has a family. Therefore, I ask you to give at once to the matter your most earnest attention, and provide for a residence intended for the teacher, either as suggested by me, or in any other way you deem the most convenient.

The school attendance has been very good last winter, most of the parents have made their duty in this respect, sending to school their children at any time, sometimes from a long distance. This fact should justify and prompt the Indian Department to make the expenses for a residence for the teacher in order to assure to the Indians of Dog Creek Reserve the just benefit of instruction to which they are entitled and which they appreciate so much.

Hoping you will comply to my request,

Yours respectfully,

Ind. Missionary.

S. Perrault, O.M.S.

April 8th, 1920.

Mr. L. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

Enclosed please find a letter of Moise Paul, Chief, requesting you to kindly appoint R. Martel as teacher of the Lake Manitoba Indian Reserve (Dog Creek) and stating that his nomination would be approved by all the Indians of the reserve, who have children.

He points out the reason of his protest sent to you last summer, as to avoid trouble he was anticipating, owing to the fact that John McLem and Paul Otchipwe, of the Dog Creek Indian Reserve, who had personal griefs against Mr. R. Martel had induced the Indians to share their animosity not because he had any serious griefs against him, as it was said in the protest. Now, the Indians have come to a better understanding, they are no more opposed to the nomination of Mr. R. Martel, at the contrary, they are unanimous in requesting his appointment at once as teacher of their school, and they will cheerfully send their children to the school under his charge.

I was sorry when you informed me that you had to cancel his nomination on account of the protest of the Indians knowing that the griefs were false, being the result of a plot against him, and injuring the reputation of Mr. Martel to great extent. The Indians had nothing to say against him when I informed them of my intention to recommend him for the position of teacher. And also I could see besides the school a nice spot well fenced, intended for garden, which Mr. Martel put up at his own expenses. It was a good object lesson for the Indians and children and an evident proof he had taken a great interest to his work.

March 15th 1920

Dear Sir,

In regard to the protest against the nomination of Paul Martel as teacher of the Indian school at Dog Creek, which I sent to the Indian Department some time last summer under my signature, I beg to say that I did so because I was anticipating trouble on the reserve, owing to the fact that two members of the Band, John McLean and Paul Lee Otehipwe, who had personal griefs against Paul Martel had succeeded in inciting the Indians to entertain prejudices and animosity against him. I must say that the griefs did have been exaggerated to a great extent, and whatever they have been in the past, they have no more effect for the present, considering the fact that Paul Martel is married since to a good woman who has been teaching previously. Therefore, all the Indians except perhaps John McLean and Paul Lee Otehipwe but they have no children themselves have no more reason to be opposed to this.
